Problem:
Imagine a function \\( z(x) \\) defined on the complex plane, where \\( z(x) = e^{iAx} \\) and A is a complex matrix. The function undergoes a Laplace transform, resulting in \\( Z(s) = \\mathcal{L}\\{e^{iAx}\\}(s) \\. Furthermore, an intervention by a matrix operator \\( M \\) is applied intermittently, transforming \\( z(x) \\) into \\( Mz(x) \).

Can the original function form \\( z(x) = e^{iAx} \\) be uniquely identified just from the result \\( Z(s) \\) without any additional information?
Explanation: Under no intervention, \\( Z(s) \\) which results from \\( z(x) = e^{iAx} \\) reflects the characteristics of the matrix A uniquely due to the direct one-to-one correspondence in the transformation process specified by the Laplace Transform of exponential functions.
